VLIB Function Reference

Grayscale Morphology

Introduction and Use Cases

Grayscale morphological operations are a common image transformation technique in computer vision processing of image.

Specification

Function

Grayscale morphology using 8-bit input arrays and a selectable flat structuring element (SE).

Variants

There are 7 operations which are directly supported through a single wrapper function (VLIB_grayscale_morphology) by passing the appropriate GrayscaleMorphologyOperation value to the operation parameter:
  • GRAYSCALE_MORPH_DILATE
  • GRAYSCALE_MORPH_ERODE
  • GRAYSCALE_MORPH_OPEN (erode followed by dilate)
  • GRAYSCALE_MORPH_CLOSE (dilate followed by erode)
  • GRAYSCALE_MORPH_TOPHAT (open followed by morphological difference)
  • GRAYSCALE_MORPH_BOTHAT (close followed by morphological difference)
  • GRAYSCALE_MORPH_GRADIENT (dilate and erode feeding separately intp the morphological difference function)

As you can see, the basic elements are the dilate, erode, and morphological difference functions. The wrapper function (VLIB_grayscale_morphology) can be bypassed and these basic functions can be directly called in any order and data dependency to achieve the above variants as well as custom variants.

Method

The method for each function is included in the API documentation links below.

Limitations

  • All basic structure element shapes are supported, e.g MxN, 1xN, Mx1.
  • No decomposition scheme is supported inside the API, structuring element is used as provided by user. However better cycle performance can be achieved if structure elements are decomposed into smaller structuring elements externally, and passed iteratively to the API. E.g. a rectangular structuring element MxN ( with all element as '1') can be externally decomposed into two line structuring elements of dimension MX1 & 1xN. For Mx1 kind of structuring element, further performance improvement can be achieved for specific image heights depending on M for basic erode and dilate APIs. Please refer following specific API description for further details:
    • VLIB_grayscale_dilate_mask
    • VLIB_grayscale_erode_mask

APIS

  • VLIB_grayscale_morphology
  • VLIB_grayscale_dilate_mask
  • VLIB_grayscale_erode_mask
  • VLIB_grayscale_morp_diff
  • VLIB_grayscale_gradient_mask

References
